data.title: Provide API to open a file/folder picker from an extension
Copy paste code does not automatically paste the imports in typescript
data.body:
- VSCode Version:

Version 1.9.0-insider
Commit 2cdc2b3da8f0fd5322b48747241584cf9dd98f8f
Date 2017-01-13T07:03:18.620Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

- OS Version:

Ubuntu

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Import a typescript class(A in a.ts) in another class(B in b.ts)
2. Create one more new typescript class (C in c.ts)
3. Copy code that contains class A from b.ts to c.ts; Lets say `let a = new A();`
4. Only the text copied gets pasted in c.ts, but not the `import {A} from './a'`;

#### Implementation details
When ever the user tries to copy paste the code within the editor between multiple files

1. During copy, vscode should be able to find imports corresponding to the copied text
2. During paste, it should automatically add the corresponding imports(may be more than one) aswell into the target file, along with the copied text

data.title: Adding tsconfig.json to existing Meteor project breaks Intellisense
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
I recently tried VS Code as I no longer want to pay for Webstorm. I want to gradually migrate my existing Meteor (i.e. JavaScript) project to TypeScript. Thus, I need a mixed setup that allows for `js` as well as `ts` files. As long as I don't add a `tsconfig.json` file, everything works as expected (at least as far as I can tell). I'm gonna use a Meteor package to do the TypeScript compiling, so all I want from VS Code is Syntax Checks, Auto Complete and Intellisense. I don't need VS Code to do any compilations. But I still need a `tsconfig.json` file to configure the Meteor TypeScript compiler. And also I can't get VS Code to recognize typings for Meteor. I was hoping I could use `tsconfig.json` to point VS Code to those type definitions. But one after the other...

Syntax Checking, Autocomplete and Intellisense working (without `tsconfig.json`):
![index ts - admin - visual studio code_005](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11458212/22061639/28ee5796-dd76-11e6-8dae-a8dbc2e3be5b.png)

Then I add an empty `tsconfig.json`, which is [permitted](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html). What happens is that instantly there is no more Syntax Checking, Autocomplete and Intellisense in `js` as well as `ts` files. Forcing suggestions with `Ctrl + Space` just gives this:
![index ts - admin - visual studio code_006](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11458212/22061747/abefeee8-dd76-11e6-9bbc-969af71a79ca.png)

Relaunching VS Code makes no difference. Interestingly, suggestions do still work inside of `tsconfig.json`:
![tsconfig json - admin - visual studio code_007](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11458212/22061853/22d92bb4-dd77-11e6-8ea3-6bfe4a28c79f.png)

I also tried adding content to `tsconfig.json` (derived from [here](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html)) and reloading VS Code
```javascript
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "system",
        "allowJs": true
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}
```
but nothing changes. No more Syntax Checks, no more Auto Complete, no more Intellisense. Removing `tsconfig.json` and reloading VS Code brings it all back.

So I'm stuck. Please Help! Thank you!

**Note 1**: I can't reproduce this issue when I open a new and empty project, then add a `ts` and a `js` file and then add a `tsconfig.json` file. In this new project everything works as expected.

**Note 2**: This project has a pretty large codebase and unfortunately I cannot share it for others to investigate.

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.1 Rebecca

Steps to Reproduce: Unfortunately unknown

data.title: Activity design for panel switcher
data.body:
Now that we have the panel switcher added, we should think about how to show activity. For example, the "Problems" view today changes its title based on the number of problems:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/22062920/680411e0-dd7c-11e6-9eeb-c53cb066b374.png)

I think this model no longer works nicely with the switcher and I would suggest we have something like the badges in the activity bar for panels too.

Thoughts?

/cc @sandy081

data.title: Double ${workspaceRoot} in launch.json
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: insiders
- OS Version: os x

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open our smoketest example https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express
2. Delete the launch.json
3. Create the launch.json by pressing the configure action and choosing node
4. Notice the "program" has the double `${workspaceRoot}`, namely: `"program": "${workspaceRoot}/${workspaceRoot}/bin/www"`

data.title: Allow extensions to handle launching of the debug adapter
data.body: Added support for new `adapterExecutableCommand` in package.json. If a command ID is specified for this, VS Code will execute the command for determining the executable path and arguments of a debug adapter (instead of using the `program`,  `args`, `runtime` and `runtimeArgs` from the package.json).

data.title: File path case-insensitivity on Windows
data.body:
[As requested](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12922#issuecomment-273415314) by @isidorn, I'm filing this issue separately.

The issue of case-insensitivity on Windows is basically breaking everything with my experience in C/C++ development, especially when using MSVC toolchain. I have duplicate files opened most of the time (that are not with same path according to `vscode`, therefore they function as two distinct files):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/421916/22060213/31962096-dd70-11e6-81a7-cc0825862618.png)

The problem often (like every 5 minutes) results in this:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/421916/22060215/3884c7d6-dd70-11e6-9b7f-a86d905fc602.png)

Which in turn results in a lot of changes being lost, or serious time waste in trying to merge the two files.

In my humble opinion, this is a major issue in the `vscode` core for anyone trying to use Windows-only command-line tools. And so it is a problem for extension creators on Windows, as they are required to be extra careful with case-sensitivity required currently by `vscode`, which does not follow platform guidelines for handling paths.

Also it is very easy to get to this state (using MSVC `cppvsdbg`), which is the biggest problem:
1. Open a file from *Explorer*.
2. One of the following:
  a. Put breakpoint to a C/C++ file. Run debug and get a new file instance each time you step (so even if you close it, the next step will reopen the same file).
  c. Open an issue from *Problems* view and get a new file instance.
  d. Open a file from external application with different case in the path (cmd, Total Commander, etc.) and get a new file instance.

In fact you can have dozens of instances of the same file.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/421916/22060284/7215020e-dd70-11e6-8c80-10e093ba1cd5.png)

data.title: ListView fails bad with large data
Windows keybinding with REST extension

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider (Date 2017-01-18)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install REST extension
2. Keybinding is: { "key": "ctrl+alt+e",            "command": "rest-client.switch-environment" },

The problem:
When I press: AltGr+e the command is executed.

Normally I should get special letter that is bonded with national keyboard mapping in Windows.

The issue has possibly two aspects:
1. The command for REST extension should not be executed as it's ctrl+alt+e not alt-e
2. The key binding AltGr+<char> is not differentiated from Alt+<char> - i believe this is related to issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17521

data.title: ContentProvider, model creation and embedded resource counter
data.body:
3 changes:
- Introduce ContentProvider for walkThrough: scheme. Only used for markdown file since TypeScript service appears (?) to only work with file: resources.
- Acquire all models in the editor input and use ITextModelResolverService to do so.
- Make StacksModel aware of the embedded resources, such that, isOpen() returns true for these. Needed to avoid DirtyFilesTracker opening additional editors and prevent TextFileEditorModelManager from disposing the embedded models as 'unused'.

data.title: Markdown fixes
data.body: Added several languages and fixed a typo in `markdown.tmLanguage`.

data.title: Display one decimal place for extensions downloads in Millions
data.body:
Fixes #18605 
Shows one decimal place if available, e.g. 1M or 1.5M.

data.title: Step through "locations" you visited in the code
data.body: It would be very useful if one was able to retrace ones steps/locations in the code based on what members/code chunks you have clicked on. This is very useful if you go through the code and ctrl+click on a function, object reference or extension that make you jump to the new file/place directly and you then want to find you way back. Also being able to go step by step forward again can be very handy. A little bit like "back" and "forward" in a web browser.

data.title: Outline members of a file in a panel
data.body:
I miss very much a outlining tool to give an good overview of members in a file to see a list of namespaces, classes, their methods and var and see if they are private protected public static abstract etc and se if the are constructors etc. It would also be very useful to be able to click on a member to directly jump to it in the code. 

I know there have been similar requests before. One that suggested to be able to see members in the explorer has been added to the backlog. What I suggest though is a separate panel showing the outline/overview/member-tree for the current file, similar to the "outline panel" in eclipse. Ideally it would also be able to be open at the same time as the explorer panel.

It would be useful if one could have the list sorted both "naturally" as it comes in the code but also be able to sort it alphabetically and apply filters on it (see only public/protected/private or vars or methods etc) to customize the result. 

Be able to choose if it should include members of parent classes in the scope or not would also be very nice. 

Further it would also be helpful to be able to rearrange the "natural order" by drag and drop to reorganize the file. #

data.title: Integrated terminal closes as soon as I attempt to open it.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-34-generic

|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|

|Go|lukehoban|0.6.52|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.3|
|wordcount|ms-vscode|0.1.0|
|Spell|seanmcbreen|0.9.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Attempt to open integrated terminal.
2. It closes on its own, with no indication of errors.

The console in Developer Tools shows nothing related to this, and I can reproduce this issue even with my most recently installed extensions disabled.
